sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving solids
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction: 

2H2(g) + O2(g) --> 2H2O(l)

Given the following enthalpies of formation: 

∆Hf°(H2O, l) = -285.8 kJ/mol 

∆Hf°(H2, g) = -241.8 kJ/mol 

∆Hf°(O2, g) = 0 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the following formula:

ΔH°(reaction) = Σ [ΔHf°(products)] - Σ [ΔHf°(reactants)]

For this reaction, we have:

ΔH°(reaction) = [2 * ΔHf°(H2O, l)] - [2 * ΔHf°(H2, g) + ΔHf°(O2, g)]

Substitute the given values:

ΔH°(reaction) = [2 * (-285.8 kJ/mol)] - [2 * (-241.8 kJ/mol) + 0 kJ/mol]

ΔH°(reaction) = (-571.6 kJ/mol) - (-483.6 kJ/mol)

ΔH°(reaction) = -88 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction is -88 kJ/mol.
